fitness_verdict:
🏠 GLASS HOUSE: Low complexity, low resilience. Simple but fragile.

Recommended Action: Add defensive patterns: error handling, timeouts, retries. Complexity will increase but reliability will improve.

priorities.action: Missing timeouts are the #1 cause of cascading failures
first_steps: Add connect_timeout and read_timeout to each
Default: 5s connect, 30s read (adjust per use case)

priorities.action: Unhandled exceptions crash processes and lose context
first_steps: Log errors with context before re-raising

priorities.action: You cannot fix what you cannot see
first_steps: Log at function entry/exit for critical paths
Include correlation IDs for request tracing

complexity_analysis.verdict: Complexity appears well-matched to task requirements. The codebase follows the principle that simplicity enables reliability.
recommendations: WARNING: 162862 lines per function point suggests over-engineering. Industry standard is ~50.

vulnerabilities.message: Bare except catches all exceptions including KeyboardInterrupt
Bare except catches all exceptions including KeyboardInterrupt
Bare except catches all exceptions including KeyboardInterrupt
Bare except catches all exceptions including KeyboardInterrupt
Bare except catches all exceptions including KeyboardInterrupt

recommendations.message: Network calls without timeouts can hang indefinitely. Add timeout configs to all HTTP clients and database connections.
Add try/catch blocks around I/O operations, network calls, and parsing logic.
Transient failures are common. Implement retry with exponential backoff for external service calls.
Insufficient logging/metrics makes debugging production issues nearly impossible.
Protect against cascading failures by adding circuit breakers to external dependencies.
Consider thread pool isolation and connection pool limits to prevent resource exhaustion.
